title: Maria Jeritza
text:
Maria Jeritza (6 October 188710 July 1982) was a celebrated <a href="Moravia">Moravia</a>n soprano singer, long associated with the Vienna State Opera, long associated with the <a href="Vienna%20State%20Opera">Vienna State Opera</a> (1912–1935) and the <a href="Metropolitan%20Opera">Metropolitan Opera</a> (1921–1932 and 1951). Her rapid rise to fame, beauty and personality earned her the nickname "The Moravian Thunderbolt".
Biography.
Jeritza was born in <a href="Brno">Brno</a> in 1887 as Mitzi Jedlicka or Marie Jedličková. She was trained at the <a href="Brno%20Conservatory">Brno Conservatory</a>, and later was a pupil of <a href="Estelle%20Liebling">Estelle Liebling</a> in New York City. In 1910, she made her debut as "Elsa", in <a href="Richard%20Wagner">Wagner's</a> "<a href="Lohengrin%20%28opera%29">Lohengrin</a>", at <a href="Olomouc">Olomouc</a>. The Emperor <a href="Franz%20Joseph%20I%20of%20Austria">Franz Josef</a> heard her and immediately ordered that she be offered a contract at the Imperial Hofoper, Vienna. She created the roles of "Blanchefleur" in <a href="Wilhelm%20Kienzl">Kienzl</a>'s <a href="opera">opera</a> "<a href="Der%20Kuhreigen">Der Kuhreigen</a>" (1911), Ariadne in <a href="Richard%20Strauss">Strauss's</a> "<a href="Ariadne%20auf%20Naxos">Ariadne auf Naxos</a>" (1912), the Empress in his "<a href="Die%20Frau%20ohne%20Schatten">Die Frau ohne Schatten</a>" (1919), and Hariette/Juliette in <a href="Erich%20Wolfgang%20Korngold">Korngold's</a> "<a href="Die%20tote%20Stadt">Die tote Stadt</a>" (Hamburg, 1920), though later became famous for her leading role of Marietta/Marie in the same opera in its January 1921 Vienna premiere, which was also the role in which she debuted at the <a href="Metropolitan%20Opera">Metropolitan Opera</a> on 19 November 1921.
On 16 November 1926, she starred in the title role of <a href="Giacomo%20Puccini">Puccini's</a> "<a href="Turandot">Turandot</a>" in its North American premiere at the Metropolitan, where she also created the title or leading soprano roles in <a href="Leo%C5%A1%20Jan%C3%A1%C4%8Dek">Janáček</a>'s "<a href="Jen%C5%AFfa">Jenůfa</a>" (1924), <a href="Ermanno%20Wolf-Ferrari">Wolf-Ferrari</a>'s "<a href="I%20gioielli%20della%20Madonna">I gioielli della Madonna</a>" (1925), Korngold's "<a href="Violanta">Violanta</a>" (1927), Richard Strauss's "<a href="Die%20%C3%A4gyptische%20Helena">Die Ägyptische Helena</a>" (1928), and <a href="Franz%20von%20Supp%C3%A9">Suppé</a>'s "Boccaccio" (1931) and "Donna Juanita" (1932). She was as popular at the Metropolitan as in Vienna, especially as <a href="Tosca">Tosca</a>, <a href="Carmen">Carmen</a> and <a href="Jules%20Massenet">Massenet</a>'s <a href="Tha%C3%AFs%20%28opera%29">Thaïs</a>. She appeared in an early sound film <a href="Grossf%C3%BCrstin%20Alexandra">Grossfürstin Alexandra</a> for which <a href="Franz%20Leh%C3%A1r">Franz Lehár</a> wrote the song 'Du und ich sind für einander bestimmt'.
After a two-year marriage to a man named Friedrich Wiener, she married an Austrian Baron, Leopold Salvator Freiherr Popper von Podhragy (1886-1986). She married her third husband in 1935, Hollywood mogul <a href="Winfield%20R.%20Sheehan">Winfield R. Sheehan</a>, who died in 1945. In 1948 she married New Jersey businessman Irving Seery and moved to a mansion in the <a href="Forest%20Hill%2C%20Newark%2C%20New%20Jersey">Forest Hill</a> neighborhood of <a href="Newark%2C%20New%20Jersey">Newark, New Jersey</a>, where she lived until her death in 1982, at the age of 94. She died in <a href="Orange%2C%20New%20Jersey">Orange, New Jersey</a>, and was buried at <a href="Holy%20Cross%20Cemetery%2C%20North%20Arlington%2C%20New%20Jersey">Holy Cross Cemetery</a> in <a href="North%20Arlington%2C%20New%20Jersey">North Arlington, New Jersey</a>. <a href="Richard%20Strauss">Richard Strauss</a> dedicated his final song <a href="Malven">Malven</a> to her, but she would not allow the manuscript to be seen by anyone during her lifetime. After her death, the Strauss family allowed it to be performed in public for the first time by <a href="Kiri%20te%20Kanawa">Kiri te Kanawa</a>, who has also recorded it.
Jeritza made a number of 78-rpm recordings which testify to the high quality of her voice. Many of these recordings have been released on CD.
